The Liverpool Dockers topped the Manchester Comets, 3-2, in Northern Conference action at Mersey Field. The player of the game was Liverpool pitcher Nicky Beedell. The Dockers bumped their record to 11-9 with this latest triumph.

Marcus Judkins was the walk-off hero for Liverpool. With the game tied in the bottom of the ninth inning, the Dockers second baseman hit a dramatic run-scoring triple to send the teams home.

"It was just a matter of executing," said Liverpool manager Owen Wilson.

fields.title: Bulls Roll to 9-3 Win Over Rhinos
fields.content:
Bristol right fielder Keith Mountford made his presence felt in the 9-3 Bulls triumph over the Birmingham Rhinos. Mountford went 2-4 with a home run and a walk. He scored 3 runs. Freddie Wray got the win, improving to 6-1. He pitched 6.2 innings, giving up 9 hits and 3 runs, while striking out 3 and walking 2. The Bulls' win now puts them at 10-12.

Bert MacBean, who is tied for 8th in the SC in total bases with 40, aided the Bristol cause with a 2-run single in the top of the sixth. For the game, the second baseman went 2-4 with a double. He drove in 3 runs and scored once.

"We put it together today and came out with the win," Mountford said in postgame remarks. "That's the main thing."

fields.title: Kings Lose, 8-2, at Llandaff Fields
fields.content:
Cardiff Dragons starter Bernard Stobert kept the London Kings hitters in check, leading his team to a comfortable 8-2 win. Cardiff now owns a record of 10-12.

The Dragons had to work out of trouble in the top of the ninth. The score was 8-2, Cardiff, with one out. London, with the bases loaded, was mounting a threat. Colin Carter dug in at the plate, but on a 1-0 fastball, he hit into a double play.

fields.title: Judkins Goes Off, But Comets Win
fields.content:
Liverpool got a terrific performance from second baseman Marcus Judkins, but it wasn't enough to beat the Manchester Comets. Manchester won the Mersey Field contest, 9-7.

Judkins was the player of the game despite being on the losing side. He was 3-4 with 2 home runs, while adding 5 RBI and scoring twice. At 13-8, the Comets have a slim two-game lead in the Northern Conference.

It could have been a different outcome for Manchester, had it not been for Carlos Vega, the four-time All-Star . Vega contributed a run-scoring walk in the top of the fifth inning to put Manchester up, 6-4.

"Win or lose, we pick each other up in this clubhouse," Vega told the Manchester Observer.

fields.title: López Lifts Harps to 5-0 Win
fields.content:
The Dublin Harps topped the Glasgow Leopards, 5-0, with catcher Jorge López playing a big role. López went 4 for 4 with a home run, a double, and 2 singles. He scored 2 runs and drove in 2 for the Harps in the win. Dublin now owns a record of 12-10.

Glasgow had a runner on 3rd in the top of the sixth. With two out, Logan Cosgrove came to bat, hoping to do some damage. Instead, he flied out. The score remained 1-0, Dublin. The Leopards saw their comeback bid fail.

fields.title: Rhinos, Stobart Blast Bulls
fields.content:
Birmingham left fielder Harry Stobart had a 3-RBI performance, which helped his team grab a 11-1 win over the Bristol Bulls. Lee Pell closed the door for Birmingham, picking up his 1st save of the year. The Rhinos have an impressive 14-5 record.

Elton Jones, who leads the SC in runs scored with 19, chipped in for Birmingham with a 2-run home run in the bottom of the first. For the game, the first baseman had 2 hits in 4 at-bats with 1 home run, 1 single, 3 runs scored, and 4 runs batted in.

"We looked pretty good up and down," said Birmingham manager Matt Sharland.

fields.title: Dragons Stun Kings, 3-2
fields.content:
The Cardiff Dragons picked up a win at Llandaff Fields, knocking off the London Kings, 3-2. Starting pitcher Kian Turnbull played a key role in the triumph. Cardiff reliever Everton Southworth was the winner. His record is now 3-0. Julian Murcott took the loss. Cardiff has a 3-game win streak, while London has lost 3 in a row.

José López was the walk-off hero for Cardiff. With the game tied in the bottom of the ninth inning, the Dragons catcher hit a dramatic run-scoring double to send the teams home.

"It's great to get the crowd pumped up," López said.

fields.title: Comets Win at Liverpool, 6-2
fields.content:
Getting a good performance from designated hitter Ashley Carruthers, the Manchester Comets defeated the Liverpool Dockers, 6-2. Carruthers went 4 for 4 with a double and 3 singles, while adding 2 RBI and scoring once for the Comets. Donnie Kerrigan was credited with the save for Manchester, his 2nd of the season. The Comets have an impressive 14-8 record.

Christopher Abercromby drew 1 walk for Manchester. The four-time All-Star had a key at-bat in the top of the sixth. With one out and runners on 1st and 3rd, he broke a 2-2 tie with a run-scoring sacrifice fly off Kirk Beacan. It was his 12th RBI of the season.

"It was a solid team effort and we'll try to keep this momentum going," Carruthers told reporters after the game.

fields.title: Harps Stymie Glasgow, Take 5-1 Win
fields.content:
Dublin third baseman Bum-kyoo Kang had 3 ribbies while helping his team defeat the Glasgow Leopards, 5-1. Howard Straw, who went 8 innings, was the winning pitcher. He was charged with 1 run on 6 hits, while walking 1 and striking out 6. His record now stands at 3-2. Dublin has 3 straight wins, Glasgow 3 straight losses.

Early in the game, Kang had a 2-run home run for Dublin. It was his 3rd home run of the season and put the Harps on top, 2-0.

"I felt we were ready to go," said Dublin manager Aaron MacCrimmon. "Our pregame was pretty good."

fields.title: Victory Pushes Rhinos Record to 15-5
fields.content:
The Birmingham Rhinos topped the Bristol Bulls, 6-3, in Southern Conference action at Edgbaston Field. The player of the game was Birmingham right fielder Stephen Longstaff.

Birmingham reliever Ross MacAsgill picked up the win, upping his record to 2-0. Sam Morrison was saddled with the loss. Birmingham leads the Southern Conference by 5½ games.

Caoimhín Crummock drew 2 walks for Birmingham. The fan favorite had a key at-bat in the bottom of the sixth. With one out and runners on 2nd and 3rd, he broke a 2-2 tie with a run-scoring sacrifice fly off Manobu Okazaki. It was his 1st RBI of the season.

"We try to keep the mood light around here," said Crummock. "Winning helps."

fields.title: Carruthers Helps Manchester Cruise to 10-3 Win
fields.content:
The rain made it unbearable at times; nonetheless, the faithful who endured the elements at The Meadow enjoyed themselves.

The Manchester Comets dealt the Dublin Harps a 10-3 loss at The Meadow. Ashley Carruthers was the star on offense. He went 4-4 with a double and 3 singles. He scored 3 runs and drove in 2. Manchester has now won 3 in a row.

Joseph Ramsay had a chance to do some damage in the top of the ninth. With Dublin trailing 10-2, Dublin had the bases loaded. Ramsay hit a sacrifice fly. But it was not enough. Dublin would not finish the comeback.

fields.title: Dockers Get Road Win, 9-5
fields.content:
Liverpool shortstop Luca Addems had 3 ribbies while helping his team defeat the Glasgow Leopards, 9-5. The Dockers bumped their record to 12-11 with this latest triumph.

Douggie Fairless, who leads the NC with a .344 batting average, chipped in for Liverpool with a 2-run single in the top of the third. For the game, the left fielder had 2 hits in 5 at-bats with 1 home run, 1 single, 1 run scored, and 3 RBI.

"We swung the bats good throughout the lineup," said Liverpool skipper Owen Wilson.

fields.title: Bulls Subdue Cardiff, 5-3
fields.content:
Fans who gathered at Netham Park saw a good contest between the Bristol Bulls and Cardiff Dragons.

Bristol starter Freddie Wray pitched effectively against the Cardiff Dragons at Netham Park. The right-hander led his team to a 5-3 win. Fraser Kirbishly closed it out for his 4th save.

Bristol took a 5-3 lead on Nick Evered's 6th home run of the season. The 3-run home run came off Cardiff pitcher Gary Kilminster in the bottom of the seventh.

"The beers will taste better tonight after this win," said the ever-candid Wray.

Bristol now sits in third place in the Southern Conference at 11-14.

fields.title: Joysey Bashes 5 Base Hits
fields.content:
The Birmingham Rhinos might think twice next time about pitching to Bert Joysey.

At Primrose Hill Park today, the London Kings second baseman burned Birmingham pitching, going 5-for-5 in a 4-3 London triumph.

"When he's on his game," London skipper Kieran Kinsella told reporters, "he can probably stroke a base hit blindfolded." 

Bert Joysey singled in the 3rd, singled in the 5th, singled in the 7th, singled in the 9th and doubled in the 11th.

fields.title: Dockers Top Leopards in Extras
fields.content:
The Liverpool Dockers defeated the Glasgow Leopards, 11-9, at Cowlairs Park. Liverpool catcher Freddie McKeterick was named player of the game for his superb performance. He was 3-5 with a home run and 2 singles. He scored 2 times.

Liverpool reliever Ben Tidcombe picked up the win, upping his record to 4-1. Samuel Serginson took the loss. The current losing streak for Glasgow has reached 5 games.

The Dockers beat the Leopards with some clutch hitting. The single by Joe Denman in the top of the 12th is a good example. With two down, Denman gave his team the lead, 10-9, when he came through with the big hit.

In postgame comments, McKeterick said he was glad to contribute to an exciting win.

fields.title: Letheren Leads Bulls to Win
fields.content:
It was a fun time at Netham Park, where the Cardiff Dragons and Bristol Bulls tangled.

Gareth Letheren made an impact in the 23-6 Bristol win over Cardiff. Letheren, who is rated as the 12th best prospect by BNN, went 3 for 5 with 3 doubles and a walk, while scoring 4 runs and driving in 4. Pat Lafontaine earned the win for Bristol. He lasted 7.1 innings, allowing 3 earned runs on 5 hits, while striking out 10. With the win, he raised his record to 2-4. 

David Jackman, who is tied for 2nd in the SC in RBI with 19, chipped in for Bristol with a 3-run home run in the bottom of the fourth. For the game, the center fielder had 2 hits in 4 at-bats with 1 home run, 1 single, 1 run scored, and 6 runs batted in.

"Baseball is about momentum," said Letheren, "and we feel we've got it in our favor after that win."

With the win, Bristol has a record of 12-14. Cardiff falls to 11-14.

fields.title: Kings Solve Rhinos, 6-4
fields.content:
The London Kings defeated the Birmingham Rhinos, 6-4, in Southern Conference action at Primrose Hill Park, with London pitcher Clyde Dooley named player of the game. The Kings saw their win-loss record go to 11-14. At the same time, the Rhinos fell to 15-7.

Had Alastair Cosh not delivered a key base hit in the bottom of the seventh, the outcome might have been different. Instead, with two down and runners on 1st and 2nd, Cosh hit a run-scoring single. That made the score 5-4, in favor of the Kings.

"Winning the game is always the first objective," Cosh said.

fields.title: Leopards Solve Dockers, 5-2
fields.content:
Glasgow third baseman Lucas Coote had a 3-RBI game, which helped his team beat the Liverpool Dockers, 5-2. Even with the win, the Leopards have a dismal 8-18 record.

The Leopards got a big at-bat from right fielder Jamie O'Gunning. For the game, O'Gunning went 1-4 with a home run. In the bottom of the sixth, with the bases empty, he stroked a solo home run. His 5th home run of the season gave Glasgow a 3-2 lead.

"This level of focus will win us a lot of ballgames," O'Gunning said after the game.

fields.title: O'Merry Hits 2 home runs in Kings Win
fields.content:
The London Kings beat the Birmingham Rhinos, 7-5, at Primrose Hill Park. The win was largely due to the efforts of first baseman Dean O'Merry, who captured player of the game honors. He hit 2 home runs. He scored 3 runs and drove in 3. Kyle Lawley finished to wrap up his 2nd save. London has a 3-game win streak, while Birmingham has lost 3 in a row.

O'Merry had a game-changing home run in the bottom of the sixth. On a 1-1 fastball from Ross MacAsgill, he banged a 2-run home run to left, giving the Kings a 6-5 lead. It was the 2nd home run of the year for O'Merry.

"We'll pop the top on a cold one and get back to work tomorrow," O'Merry said.

fields.title: Comets Lose, 4-1, at Cowlairs Park
fields.content:
Glasgow Leopards starter Brad Vinter was in a rhythm all game. He led his team to a win over the Manchester Comets, 4-1, to begin today's double header. Vinter got the win, improving to 3-5. He allowed 4 hits and walked 3 over 7 innings. Vinter allowed 1 earned run. Lysagh Hooper closed the door for Glasgow, picking up his 4th save of the year.

Eisaku Nishimura was a key contributor to the win for the Leopards. In the bottom of the first with two out, the light-hitting shortstop stroked a single to center. He went 1-3. He drove in 2 runs.

"Whenever we hold the other team to one run," said Leopards manager Freddy MacKenzie, "I like our chances." 

Even with the win, the Leopards have a dismal 9-18 record.

fields.title: Dockers Win in Extras
fields.content:
The Liverpool Dockers eked out a 2-1 win versus the Dublin Harps at Tolka Baseball Field. Nobody did more than pitcher Nicky Beedell, who captured player of the game honors.

Liverpool reliever Ben Tidcombe picked up the win, upping his record to 5-1. Kai Easterbrook took the loss. The Dockers bumped their record to 14-12 with this latest triumph.

The Dockers beat the Harps with some clutch hitting. The single by Luca Addems in the top of the tenth is a good example. With two down, Addems gave his team the lead, 2-1, when he came through with the big hit.

"Big win," said Addems.

fields.title: London Decked by Butler, Bulls
fields.content:
The Bristol Bulls beat the London Kings, 8-3, at Primrose Hill Park. The win was largely due to the efforts of third baseman Jack Butler, who captured player of the game honors. He went 2 for 2 with 2 home runs and 3 walks. He drove in 4 runs and scored twice. Bristol now has a 3-game win streak.

Butler had a big at-bat with a runner on 1st in the top of the first inning, when he hit a 2-run home run. The Bulls went on to win.

"We maximized our offense today," said Bristol skipper Carl Gillespie. "That makes everyone's life easier."

fields.title: Méndez Gets No-Hitter Against Cardiff
fields.content:
After leading the Birmingham Rhinos to victory, 7-0, and tossing the seventh no-hitter in league history against the Cardiff Dragons, Bartolo Méndez didn't have the answer.

"I don't know," Méndez said. "To do what I did today, I'm pretty sure it takes both."

On his big day at Llandaff Fields, Méndez fanned 5 and had 1 walk. And it seemed that when the Dragons managed to hit the ball hard, it went right at a defender. Even though the game was shortened to just five and a half-innings by rain, it still counts as a no-hitter.

"That's how you get a no-hitter," Méndez said with a smile. "A lot of skill mixed with a little luck."

To date this year Méndez has compiled a 5-3 mark with a 3.34 ERA in 10 starts.

fields.title: Leopards Bang Out 7-2 Win Versus Manchester
fields.content:
Glasgow left-hander David Hogarth made an effective start against the Manchester Comets at Cowlairs Park, leading his team to a 7-2 win. Glasgow is now riding a 3-game win streak after sweeping a double header.

Early in the game, designated hitter Andrew Budge had a 2-run double for Glasgow. It was his 4th double of the season and put the Leopards on top, 4-2.

"We put a lot of pressure on ourselves," Hogarth told a Glasgow Citizen reporter. "Sometimes we need just to relax."

fields.title: Harps Sneak Past Dockers, 5-4
fields.content:
Dublin Harps starter Jorge Rodríguez was in a groove as he led his team to a win over the Liverpool Dockers, 5-4. Dublin reliever Lyndon Achurch was the winner. His record is now 1-0. The losing pitcher was Reece Wellings. The Harps bumped their record to 14-12 with this latest triumph.

Dermott Singleton was the walk-off hero for Dublin. With the game tied in the bottom of the ninth inning, the Harps shortstop hit a dramatic run-scoring single to send the teams home.

"This place was rocking at the end," Rodríguez said.

fields.title: Bulls Edge Past Kings, 2-1
fields.content:
The Bulls had to overcome a fine performance from London pitcher Clyde Dooley to grab a 2-1 win at Primrose Hill Park. Dooley allowed 1 earned run over 8 innings. Fraser Kirbishly got credit for the win, improving to 1-1. He allowed no runs on 3 hits in 2 innings. Bristol now has a 4-game win streak.

Late-game drama came in the top of the ninth inning. With one out and a runner on 1st, the batter, David Jackman, hit a single. It helped Bristol seize the win.

"Enjoyed this one," Jackman told the Bristol Chronicle. "But it's back to work tomorrow."

fields.title: Victory Pushes Rhinos Record to 17-8
fields.content:
Birmingham right-hander Peter Maxwell pitched his team to victory over the Cardiff Dragons at Llandaff Fields. The final score was 5-1. Maxwell, now 7-0, was the winner. In 6.2 innings, he gave up 6 hits, while striking out 0, walking 2, and allowing 1 earned run. Cardiff's current losing streak has reached 4 games.

The Rhinos got a big at-bat from center fielder Jacob Ransley. For the game, Ransley was 2-4 with 2 singles. In the top of the second, with runners on 1st and 2nd, he stroked a run-scoring single. His 25th hit of the season gave Birmingham a 1-0 lead.

"We'll pop the top on a cold one and get back to work tomorrow," Maxwell said.

fields.title: Cardenas Hits 2 home runs in Comets Win
fields.content:
The Manchester Comets handed the Glasgow Leopards a loss at Cowlairs Park. The final score was 5-3. Luis Cardenas was named player of the game for Manchester. In addition to his 1 single and 2 home runs, he scored 2 runs and drove in 3. He also added 1 walk. Gabriel Attrill closed the game out for Manchester, earning his 9th save. The Comets bumped their record to 16-10 with this latest triumph.

Cardenas had a big at-bat with a runner on 1st in the top of the third inning, when he hit a 2-run home run. The Comets went on to win.

Cardenas told a Manchester Observer reporter that he was "more than satisfied" with the win.

fields.title: Bulls Fall Short, 4-3, at London
fields.content:
The Bristol Bulls got a superb performance from pitcher Sam Morrison, but the London Kings still won the game, 4-3. Morrison was named the player of the game despite the loss. He threw 8 innings allowing 4 runs. The win was Noburo Tsuchiya's in relief. His record improves to 1-0. Sam Morrison took the loss for Bristol. Kyle Lawley finished the game for London and earned his 3rd save.

Had Richard Minto not delivered a key base hit in the bottom of the seventh, the outcome might have been different. Instead, with two down and a runner on 2nd, Minto hit a run-scoring double. That made the score 4-3, in favor of the Kings.

"It's nice to come out on top today," said Minto.

London is now 13-16, while Bristol is 14-15.

fields.title: Dragons Drop Another One
fields.content:
Birmingham got a strong outing from Dan Philkin as the Rhinos defeated the Cardiff Dragons, 3-2, at Llandaff Fields. Philkin went 8 innings to notch the win. He scattered 5 hits, walked 2, and struck out 2. His record improves to 1-0. The last-place Dragons have lost 5 straight games.

It could have been a different outcome for Birmingham, had it not been for Bartley Kilvington, the 2017 Rookie of the Year winner . Kilvington contributed a run-scoring single in the top of the second inning to put Birmingham up, 3-0.

Cardiff manager Jacob Hanbury said he was "mildly disappointed" with the loss. "We had our opportunities, but we didn't take advantage of them," he said.

fields.title: Ellis Rodmell
fields.content:
Just like everyone else connected with the league, I was absolutely horrified to hear the news of Ellis' accident yesterday. We all knew that at the age of 36 and with playing time having been very limited last year, he was probably edging towards the end of his career anyway but nobody could have imagined it would come so soon and in these circumstances.

At one point last night it sounded as though we might lose Ellis, although from what I gather this morning the news is good and his condition has stabilised. At times like this nothing is more important than the player's health and the end of a playing career is of little significance compared to what might have happened, but such a loyal servant to the club deserved to be able to make the decision about when to retire himself.

That has been taken away from him now, so all we can do is wish Ellis and his family all the best and hope to see him back at Netham Park soon watching the Bulls in action.

Get well soon Ellis!

fields.title: Bouncing Back
fields.content:
There's no hiding away from it - last season was really disappointing for us. Although I'd have loved our run to go on, we know that we can't win the title every year and after four championships in a row, it had to end some time. Ending is one thing though, ending by finishing up in last place in our Conference with our worst season in a decade was quite a nasty shock.

I really think it was just a one-off though. I look at our team, and the others in the Northern Conference, and I still think that player for player we have the best roster. I'm really not sure what went wrong in 2017, I suppose everyone has a bad year now and then, but we really shouldn't panic. It was a shame that Ronald Rider couldn't retire on the back of a title success, but I think he's earned his time off and maybe the change will be a good thing for us.

I think we've made a really good appointment in Marcus Utting, who was unlucky not to win at least one championship with London. He looks like the man to lead us back to the top and I really think we can be celebrating a record-equalling fifth title come the autumn!

fields.title: Spring Training
fields.content:
It's really hard as a Bulls fan to be optimistic about the season ahead after our performances during Spring Training. We all knew that Birmingham were going to be the team to beat this season in the Southern Conference but the way they scored runs with such ease in the last two games against us shows how far we have to go to be able to compete with them, especially in terms of pitching.

It's vital that we get off to a good start this season as if we let Birmingham get a few games clear of us in the first half of the season, it's hard to imaging being able to catch them. London's form in Spring Training really took me by surprise, I would never have expected them to be within a single game of the Rhinos, so our opening weekend series against London will be a good gauge of where we are at the moment.

Some of the predictions I've seen have had us finishing with a losing record this season - I'm never the most optimistic of fans but even I think that's a bit negative! We should have a winning season most definitely, but I can't bring myself to believe that we have enough strength in the squad to be able to challenge Birmingham.

fields.title: Shambolic Pitching
fields.content:
Well, the optimism of taking two out of three games against London last weekend didn't stick around for long. This weekend was a clear example of why there is absolutely no way we can possibly hope to challenge Birmingham at the moment. Losing games to a good team I can accept, but to give up 31 runs in three games is just nowhere near acceptable from our pitching staff.

Just as it looked as though we might save a little face in last night's game and get something out of the series, we threw away not one but two leads to hand them a game we should have won. You don't get too many chances to beat the best teams out there and we really wasted one.

At least we were in that game though - Friday's game and the first one yesterday were just a disgrace. For our starter to give up nine runs in the first three innings yesterday afternoon was frankly embarrassing, and the way our middle relievers crumbled on Friday when we looked to be well in the game looks like confirming all my worst fears about the way this season is going to go.

I wasn't convinced about Paul Edwards as pitching coach last year, and the fact that we managed to sneak an even record for the year probably saved his job, but if our pitching stats continue to deteriorate this season it will definitely be time for a change.

fields.title: Too Inconsistent
fields.content:
On Friday night I was feeling a little bit more optimistic about our season. Not like me really, but we had won three games out of four and managed to grind out a good win against a tricky Dublin side. The events of the last two days have changed all that good feeling though. We just can't play well enough on a consistent basis against the middle of the pack teams to be able to sustain a good season.

Although we were behind heading into the ninth inning yesterday, we were still well in the game only for the bullpen to crumble yet again. Cranidge really looked like he just did not want to be out there. Still, we responded well today and overall I would have been happy with a win - Dublin have got a decent team and to take two out of three would have been a good weekend. With the 6-3 lead late on, we should have been home and dry but Kirbishley just fell apart.

It was a relief to take it into extra innings, but there was a real inevitability about losing the game in the dead of night the way we did. 8-10 at this stage of the season is probably a fair reflection of the way that we have played, but it's not a reflection of where we should be. We are underachieving again and it's largely down to the pitching staff. We are getting into winning positions, but we just can't convert them with the regularity that we should be able to.

Something needs to be done about it, it's too late for this season but with a few changes in the pitching line up we could challenge next year - maybe!

fields.title: Twenty-three - Six!
fields.content:
Anyone ever seen a game like that before? I certainly haven't. Cardiff had somehow managed to drag themselves ahead of us in the standings, which I think says far more about how poor we have been this season than it does about them. Cardiff are a poor team themselves, and we should be way ahead of them really, something which I think today illustrated quite clearly.

Even though we scored one in the first inning, I never expected the explosion of runs over the next four frames. Leading 19-2 at the end of the fifth, anyone who arrived late must have thought the scoreboard had malfunctioned again! Admittedly Cardiff helped us a lot with some dreadful fielding, but you have to make the hits and we showed that the offensive side of our team can compete with anyone in the league on their day.

All the old frailities were there again at the end though - in a tight game giving up three runs in the eighth like that could have cost us yet again. Yes it was fun to watch a game like this, but we can't get carried away. The opposition was dreadful and we still allowed them six runs. At least we're back ahead of them in the standings though, it was frankly embarrassing to be sitting below a team who can perform as badly as this!

fields.title: A Great Start
fields.content:
What a start to the regular season for the Comets! Our pre-season form was a little inconsistent, but I always try not to read too much into Spring Training games. It's what happens from now on that counts, and although Glasgow are likely to be the weakest team in our Conference this season we still have to beat them and to take all three games in the first series was just the perfect way to begin our season.

Apart from a 1-0 deficit early on Friday, we always looked in control of every game and if you take out the five runs we gave up in the ninth inning yesterday, every aspect of our play was impressive all through the weekend. It's going to get harder from here on, we play Liverpool next weekend and of course they were the team who took our title away last year. I'm sure they enjoyed the reversal of fortunes, but we will enjoy it just as much when we overtake them again this time!

They will probably be the biggest opposition we face in the Northern Conference this year, so next weekend's series will give us a good idea of where we stand against them. Being at home, we should be looking to take at least two out of the three games, but if we play like we did this weekend then maybe we can win all three again!

fields.title: Much Needed Win
fields.content:
Coming into this weekend at 8-3, our season was probably going even better than I expected! We looked like we could be opening up a bit of a gap and if we could have won Friday's game, it would have set us up nicely to take another series. Unfortunately, the bats then went a little bit quiet!

To be fair, London's pitching staff turned in some great performances in the first two games but it was disappointing to see our hitters struggling like that, something we haven't really been used to even during the struggles of last season. Losing all three games would really have given our conference rivals hope and so I think in the context of the season, winning last night's game could turn out to be one of the most important victories of the year.

We needed a good start to get some confidence back, and the four runs in the second inning certainly gave us that. Our pitching was great and with the bat, Ohoyashi showed what a great player he is going to be for us in the years to come. Now we can head into June with renewed confidence and try to extend our advantage in the standings!

fields.title: Rain!
fields.content:
I thought June was supposed to be the middle of summer?! I know we get plenty of rain in Manchester, but this weekend was so frustrating. Dublin came into the weekend closer to us than I would have liked in the standings, so it was an opportunity to put a bit of daylight between us, but we almost didn't get any games played at all!

During the rain delay on Friday the weather looked as though it was in for the day and I was actually quite surprised that the players got back out on to the field - maybe they shouldn't have as they were struggling a bit with the wet field. At least we got the win though.

It was a good job we did, as there was no way we were ever going to get any games played on Saturday or Sunday. I've really never seen rain like it at this time of year, it just never stopped and it's given us plenty of games to catch up on later in the year. Hopefully with a three game series in Glasgow next week to end the first half of the season, we can open up a little bit more of a gap to the chasing teams.

fields.title: Optimism? Fading a Bit.
fields.content:
I wanted to be optimistic heading into the 2018 season. Although the Leopards were some distance behind Liverpool last season and finished two games worse than in 2016, I thought we actually looked a better team than a year before. Our pitching was stronger and we looked a more balanced team, so the signs were good coming into the new season.

Spring Training started well too, although we weren't scoring many runs our pitching looked strong and confidence looked high. Beating Liverpool 13-1 was OK too! Having lost seven of the last eight games in pre-season though, it's tough to go into the regular season feeling good about our chances. We lost too many close games, and although you might say at least we were in with a chance, I just feel it says more about our inability to come through with the big hits when it matters.

There will be teams with worse pitching than us, and teams with worse hitting than us, but I'm just struggling to have much faith in our ability to pull out the wins in close games. We have a tough start to the season against a Manchester team who will be desperate to make up for losing the title last year, and to be honest if we can just win one game against them and then take two of three against Dublin, I would be reasonably happy with that start.

fields.title: So Far So Predictable
fields.content:
Well, we've played three games against each of our Northern Conference rivals and I'm sad to say that my pre-season expectations are coming to pass. Apart from the thrashing in the Saturday game, we didn't play too badly against Manchester and had plenty of chances on the Sunday to take a game from them, but the clutch hits wouldn't come and we lost by a run.

Against Dublin, we very nearly contrived to throw away a 6-0 lead and then having got that first win on the board, let another tight game get away from us on the Saturday. Heading into the series against the reigning champions at 1-5 doesn't look good, but we could and probably should have swept Liverpool over the past few days.

Friday's game looked to be under control until that meltdown in the seventh inning, we outhit them on the day but couldn't convert enough of our scoring chances. Saturday's win was probably our best all-round performance of the season, although they helped us with four errors, but last night was almost a carbon copy of Friday. In control in the middle innings after a great pitching display from Pat Brown, we couldn't hold the lead and when the game went to extra innings, there was an inevitability about the result.

So we sit 2-7 after nine games, a record that is worse than our performances would suggest but which reflects our inability to turn a lead into a win.

fields.title: So Frustrating
fields.content:
Yet again this past weekend summed up our season. Birmingham are clearly the best team in the league and will probably win the title, but we could very easily have taken two out of two against them before the rain ruined the chances of getting a win today.

Heading into the eighth leading 3-0 on Friday, we should have been safe after adding the insurance run to make it 4-0, but as soon as they got those two runs to close the gap you could sense the nerves as we headed into the ninth. When we didn't score in the ninth, I just had a nasty feeling that 4-2 might not be a big enough lead and so it proved. Once again our starting pitcher produced a great show, but the relievers let him down and another win slipped away.

When we got yesterday's game back to 3-2, I really thought we had a chance to complete the comeback and grab a win from a losing position for once, instead of the other way around. Instead, we handed the momentum right back to them with a sloppy inning in the seventh and another game got away from us. Birmingham won't have many two game series as tough as that this year, and I think they knew it.

I know we have better players than our 5-13 record suggests, but whatever the position in a game it's just hard to see us turning it into a win.

fields.title: What We Are Capable Of
fields.content:
This weekend the Leopards really showed how good they can be on their day, as we were unlucky not to sweep the conference leading Comets. In Saturday's double header we held a 4-0 lead very comfortably in the first game, just giving up the one run and never really looking like allowing them back into the game. Then in the second game, we bounced back so well from the bad first inning and allowed them almost nothing at all for the rest of the game.

If we could have kept Cardenas quiet yesterday we might have had the sweep, but even at 5-1 down we were creating scoring chances and still might have got the win. With the bases loaded in the eighth I though it was about to happen, but perhaps we were hoping for too much.

We reach half-way at 10-19 - honestly, we should be several games better than that and anyone who has seen our games this season will surely agree. There's not much chance of us getting out of last place in the North, but we're a better team than Cardiff so surely we won't end up with the worst record in the whole league. We deserve better than that.

fields.title: Repeat at Last?
fields.content:
Last season was amazing. Our fourth league title, seven years after the last, after dominating the Northern Conference and then overwhelming a very strong Birmingham team four games to one in the Championship Series. Now comes the biggest challenge of all - can the Dockers finally complete a successful defence of the BIBL title?

Our long term championship rivals Birmingham have done it of course - and our local rivals Manchester somehow won four in a row - but on our previous three attempts, we have always fallen short. The first one was the closest, getting back to the Championship Series only to lose in five games to Birmingham, but this time I think it might be different. I can't see anyone stopping us in the North, although Manchester will surely come back stronger after last season's collapse.

It might be Birmingham winning the South again, although London ran them very close last season, but I really feel like we have got their number at the moment. I'm more confident than at any time since the 2001 season that we can hold on to our title and match Birmingham's record of five.

fields.title: Decent So Far
fields.content:
OK, I know we are a game behind the Comets in the standings. Nobody wants to see us trailing Manchester any less than I do, but I think they are overachieving and we have had a good start to the season. If we could have edged that long extra innings game in Manchester, it would have been the Dockers with the one game lead and everyone would have been happy - that's how close we were to a brilliant start to the season.

Having a game postponed because of rain in Manchester is sort of expected really and sharing the other two was a decent outcome for us, especially as we have managed to win our other two series so far. OK, it would have been great to sweep either Dublin or Glasgow - or both - but we did the minimum that we had to do and I think it sets us up nicely for the games against the southern teams in the next few weeks.

The coming weekend gives us a great chance to show where we stand against Birmingham - hopefully carrying on where we left off in the Championship Series last year - then a series against Cardiff should give us the chance to really turn up the pressure on the Coment. I for one will be really surprised if we are not clear at the top of the standings by the end of this month.

fields.title: I Guess I'm Surprised...
fields.content:
So much for my prediction that we would have a lead in the standings by the end of May. The last two weeks have been really disappointing, there's no denying that. The two games against Birmingham were close, but really it's hard to claim you were unlucky to lose both of them when you didn't ever have a lead in either game. When we go to Birmingham later in the year, we need to be on our game right from the start and take control from the first inning.

Cardiff have been really poor this year and I expected us to beat them easily, but we were so poor on Friday. When we got back to 5-5 I backed us to go on and win, but the bullpen picked a really bad time to turn in the worst display of the year. Nicky Beedell was amazing yesterday and gave us a chance to win the series, but letting the lead slip today was so poor. Having lost four out of our last five, we're losing touch with the Comets a bit.

I'm not worried yet, but if we want to hold on to this title we need a good month in June to put ourselves back in contention by the mid-season break.

fields.title: Crucial Defeat
fields.content:
Coming into this weekend's series against the Comets trailing by two games, the Dockers really needed to take at least two out of three to close the gap. After splitting the double header on Saturday, that put huge pressure on us to take yesterday's game and unfortunately it was Manchester who coped best of all with that pressure as a vital error really cost us the game.

Having come back from a one-run deficit twice already, I'd really have backed the Dockers to get back into the game again from 3-2 down after six innings, but what should have been the third out turned into an error and you can't give Cardenas chances with two men on. He punished our defensive sloppiness and from 6-2 down, Manchester were strong enough to hold on for the win.

I know we aren't even at the half-way point of the season yet so I don't want to give the impression that I am giving up on our chances of holding onto the Northern Conference title, but to be honest a three-game gap is quite a deficit to be facing. Especially as we don't even have a winning record on the season now.

We finish the first half of the campaign against Glasgow and Dublin, then play Dublin again before a four-game series with Manchester. We need to be closer than three games going into that four-game run. That would give us the chance to really put the pressure on and maybe edge ourselves back in front again.

fields.title: A Season of Struggle
fields.content:
It's tough to have to say it, but I worry that this year could be a painful one for the Dragons. Everyone is backing us to finish the season with the worst record in the league, and we hardly set about proving people wrong by finishing Spring Training with only three wins from our twelve games.

It looks set to be our pitching the provides the biggest problem of all. OK, so our hitting line-up isn't great either, but at least in that department I think we are at least the equal of Dublin or London, to name at least two. Our pitching staff on the other hand - I'm sorry to say looks by far the weakest in the league. We will score enough runs to surprise one or two teams, as we did when we ended Birmingham's unbeaten run in pre-season, but many games we might be too far behind for it to make a difference.

The club is in a time of rebuilding, I think we have to accept that. The team that got us so close to the Southern Conference title two years ago has largely broken up and last year's fourth place finish might not be the last for a while. I just hope the fans don't get on the players' backs too quickly if we do start to struggle - everyone needs to give the club time and while it might take a year or two, we will be back.

fields.title: Remarkable Game!
fields.content:
What a tussle we saw last night (and early this morning) as the Dragons got their first win of the season against title favourites Birmingham. I've been watching this team since way back in 2000 and haven't seen too many games which changed around as many times as that one did. Only a few of us from Cardiff stayed until the bitter end, but it was worthwhile even though the journey home didn't end until about 3:30 this morning!

You wouldn't have guessed what was to come when the Dragons surged into a 7-0 lead, or even when the Rhinos turned it around to lead 10-8 - at that point most of us were expecting a capitulation from the Dragons and possibly a heavy defeat. Retaking the lead 11-10 almost immediately was certainly a shock! Getting through three innings with a one-run lead is tough for the Dragons though, especially with a rain delay to deal with, and having got so close it was heartbreaking to see Birmingham tie it right at the end.

The team stuck at the task though and although François Toussaint will get the headlines for his five hits, Dermott Woolton deserves a huge share of the credit for a massive two out hit in the eleventh. I know it's only one win and we are certainly a long way from contending with the Rhinos across a season, but this was a really enjoyable way to end the first weekend of the season.

fields.title: Better Than Expected
fields.content:
If you had suggested at the start of the regular season that we would be 7-8 after the first fifteen games, I really wouldn't have believed it. Even after a decent first series against Birmingham, going 6-6 through the month of May is way above what many people thought the Dragons were capable of this year.

Losing the series at Glasgow was disappointing, but to take two out of three from the reigning league champions this past weekend suggests that maybe we are not quite as bad a team as everyone thought! There's certainly plenty of fight in this team, coming back from a late inning deficit in yesterday's game and grinding out a win in extra innings despite making three errors in the game shows a lot of character.

It's raising my hopes a little bit that we might possibly manage to avoid finishing in last place this year!

fields.title: Humiliation
fields.content:
Awful. Embarrassing. Unacceptable. All that and more. Losing games I can accept, even losing to our local rivals, even though I don't like it. But surrender like we saw today just isn't good enough and all the players need to take a long hard look at themselves.

Our pitchers were dreadful, our fielding was absolutely shambolic and with the exception of the brief rally in the eighth inning, our hitting was almost non-existant. Bristol had been struggling a bit of late and we had a chance to put a bit of a gap between ourselves and the Bulls this weekend, but after losing yesterday and then capitulating like this today it's hard to believe was can get ahead of either them or anyone else for the foreseeable future.

To give up 18 runs across just four innings is almost unprecedented in league history I should imagine, and it's not something I want to sit through my team doing ever again. With heavy rain forecast for tomorrow, we might have a long time to sit and think about what happened this afternoon before our next game. Next weekend it's three against runaway leaders Birmingham - on today's evidence I dread to think what they might do to us.

fields.title: Reverting to Type
fields.content:
A few weeks ago I was feeling optimistic. Yes we were struggling, yes we might have still finished in last place, but at least the Dragons were showing a bit of fight. Enough to think that the club were turning things around and that the coaching staff knew what they were doing, and maybe could put together a decent team over the next couple of years.

Five successive defeats though, including that utter humiliation in Bristol and three largely anaemic batting performances against Birmingham, have put us right back where everyone thought we were at the start of the year and made those of us who were trying to claim the Dragons weren't as bad as everyone was saying look rather foolish.

With three more games against Birmingham to come after the mid-season break, it could get worse before it gets better as well. Certainly when Bristol come to Cardiff at the end of this month we are entitled to expect a reaction to what happened last week and see our team show some fight and recover a bit of pride.

I gave the management the benefit of the doubt last winter when they appointed an inexperienced manager - after all our assistant coaches have decades of experience between then and should be able to keep us on track. Maybe Jacob Hanbury is out of his depth though - if we end up with fewer wins on the board than we got last season, there will be decisions to be made this winter.

fields.title: Not Enough Runs
fields.content:
I think we all know what the Harps' problem has been so far this year! We can't score runs! After a good Spring Training, when we matched the league champions Liverpool for the best in the Northern Conference, we're trailing behind the leaders at the moment having lost a few games when our pitching really gave us a chance to win.

If you look at the statistics, our starting pitchers are among the best in the Northern Conference and we aren't giving up a lot of runs, but we are not scoring enough to take advantage of that. Last weekend we could have taken two out of three games against Manchester but we lost the Sunday game even though we outhit the Comets 11-8. Then this weekend, we outhit London 8-3 yesterday but lost 3-1! Even today we could have won the game, but London took their chances where the Harps couldn't.

We've got Birmingham next weekend - and they score so many runs that we really need to improve on taking our chances if we want to win any of those games!

fields.title: Really Good Run
fields.content:
Suddenly things are looking really good for the Dublin Harps! We were 6-9 after fifteen games at the start of this month, but now we are 13-10 after seven wins from eight games in June and it seems like our players have remembered how to score runs!

Winning series against Bristol and Cardiff was very good, especially against Bristol after we lost the first game of the three, and that gave us a chance against last placed Glasgow to really gain on Manchester in the standings. Sometimes things go wrong when we're expecting to beat a struggling team, but not this time as we dominated the Leopards.

Only giving up two runs across the three games shows you how strong our pitching can be, and when that is happening scoring five or six runs in a game like we did is more than enough. Against better teams we might need a few more runs, but the way our pitchers are performing I'm starting to think we might have a chance of challenging Manchester or Liverpool for the conference title!

fields.title: Our Year
fields.content:
I'm really confident this will be the year when the Rhinos win the BIBL title for the sixth time. I know we're all disappointed about how last season ended, losing the Championship Series in five games, but we have to remember that three of our four defeats were by a single run and we really weren't far away from taking the title. Looking at our squad this year, I think we are stronger and capable of winning the Southern Conference by a significant margin.

Our pitching in particular looks to be the class of the league, and in Elton Jones we probably have the best hitter the league has ever seen. If we do go back to the Championship Series again, it may well be our old rivals from Liverpool who are the opposition again. Their pitching looks to be strong too, so another tight, low-scoring series could be on the cards.

If that happens, we will have the memories of falling just short in 2017 driving us on and my money would be on the Rhinos to turn it around this time. I don't want to take for granted that we will win our conference, but looking at the other three teams it's honestly hard to see who will even have a winning record, let alone be able to compete with us across a 60 game season.

fields.title: Signs Are Good
fields.content:
I know everyone says you don't read too much into Spring Training, but that's usually when their team has done badly. Some of our performances, especially with the bat, have been stunning and I think just go to highlight our dominance over the other three teams in the Southern Conference.

The back-to-back wins over Cardiff and Bristol, where we scored 12 and 10 runs respectively, were awesome to watch although losing 12-1 to London the following day was a nasty shock! I like to think that was a one-off though, and a 9-3 record in Spring Training is a fantastic sign for the season to come.

If we can keep this form going, I would back us to win at least seven of the nine games against our conference rivals to start the season. If we do that, we might find that we already have a lead of a couple of games - a great platform to push on from.

fields.title: Job Done!
fields.content:
Before the season I said we could win seven of our first nine conference games - well, that's exactly what the Rhinos have managed!

It could have been better, had we held on to our lead in that ridiculous 13-11 game against Cardiff, as well as giving Bartolo Méndez better run support against London on Friday. He pitched brilliantly in that game and did not deserve to end up on the losing side, although to be fair losing would have been harsh on either pitcher in a game like that.

It might be a bit greedy though to suggest that we could have been 9-0 at this point (even though we very easily could) - I'll settle for 7-2. Especially as I suggested that seven wins could put us a couple ahead in the standings, and actually we are already leading by three. Now comes the big revenge mission against Liverpool - wins in next weekend's games won't make up for losing the Championship Series last year, but it will show where we stand this season if there might be another post-season battle to come!

fields.title: Tables Turned
fields.content:
It was a shame we didn't get the chance to go for a three-game sweep of Liverpool today, the rain denying us that chance, but it was really satisfying to turn the tables and win a couple of close games after the tough losses in similar circumstances cost us last year's title.

I won't deny I was a little worried on Friday when a 4-0 lead was closed to 4-3 in the ninth inning, but this time we managed to see it through. Liverpool haven't had the greatest start to the season but they are still the reigning champions and are still a very good team, so you know they aren't going to make things easy for you, even when they're trailing in the late innings.

They showed that again yesterday, battling back to force us to extra innings, but for the second day in a row we showed real character to get the job done in a tight situation. I think it shows that we have learned from what happened last year, there is greater mental strength in this Rhinos team and it gives me even more confidence that this is the year when we can take the title back.

fields.title: Didn't See That Coming
fields.content:
Having won 15 of our first 20 games this season, I don't think anyone expected to see the Rhinos swept by London in three games. It shouldn't have happened either, as some very uncharacteristic late inning struggles cost us very dearly in all three games.

Letting slip the lead in the ninth inning on Friday was disappointing, but at least it was only a one-run lead in a tight game which saw the Kings out hit us anyway. Leading 4-2 in the 7th on Saturday, we should have been able to see that one through but Lee Pell's pitching was poor - I'm not really convinced that he is up to the job of pitching in this league on a regular basis. If we have a big lead maybe, but not in a close game.

Yesterday was the worst one of all though. Up 5-0 in the second, we looked to be cruising and I think the players thought so as well. We took our foot off the gas, threw a couple of careless pitches to O'Merry and he punished us. It was a game we should have won, and we don't usually throw away positions like that. Maybe at 15-5 we were getting a bit complacent and assuming we could just beat teams easily - this could be the wake-up we needed!

fields.title: No No-Hitter?
fields.content:
When is a no-hitter not a no-hitter? Possibly yesterday. Don't get me wrong, Bartolo Méndez pitched brilliantly and I was really caught up in the excitement of the announcement of a no-hitter when the game was called off because of the rain - it was the first one I've ever seen in person.

Having a while to think on it though, is it really a no-hitter? I've seen pitchers go longer than five innings without giving up a hit, but lose the no-hitter because the game is, understandably, still going on. It's not the pitcher's fault that it rains, and the game can't be completed, but on the other hand it isn't really up with the achievements of pitchers who have got through the full nine innings without giving up a hit.

I'll still enjoy having seen it happen, but I think I'll be even more excited when I finally see a no-hitter that has lasted the full nine innings.

fields.title: McGregor Brilliant
fields.content:
Things are looking up for the Kings, and Cameron McGregor is a big part of the reason why. When we lost seven of our first ten games, things weren't looking good but some really good pitching all around has started to turn round our season. Today, McGregor gave us the best example of that yet!

Only allowing four baserunners across eight innings, and only two of those from base hits, was a magnificent performance from a player who some of the 'experts' would have had you believe was past his best. I thought it was a shame that he wasn't allowed to go back out for the ninth to try to get the complete game shutout, but to be fair he had thrown nearly 120 pitches. Five or so years ago, maybe, but probably better to protect his arm now.

Having had a bad start, I think it's already too late for us to be thinking about the possibility of competing with Birmingham this year, which is disappointing after how close we ran them last year. I think we look good to be able to finish second in the conference this season though - if we can do that and finish with a winning record too, it would be a good platform to build from for next year.

fields.title: Not Good Enough
fields.content:
This season is fast turning into a real disappointment for the Kings. Losing seven of our last nine games is bad enough, but to drop a game like yesterday's defeat to Cardiff was just dreadful. Thanks to the rain, we haven't even had a chance to make up for it today.

To be fair, yesterday's game really could have gone either way but having got the 2-0 lead thanks to two runs in the ninth, we should have been able to hold on. Giving up a lead-off home run is never a good sign in that situation, it brought the Cardiff fans right back into the game and gave their players hope that they could get back into the game.

I thought the Kings might just get away with it when we got the next two outs, but Julian Murcott just threw a bad pitch to Chantler and got punished for it. Even though there were two out, there was something inevitable about the Dragons getting the winning run after that. I'm not really sure why Murcott stayed in the game, his head didn't seem to be in the right place, but he never looked like getting either of the next two hitters out and the Dragons got the win.

The way things are going, we will be lucky to avoid finishing last this year - which is something I never thought I'd say after a good season last year and a great run in Spring Training this year.

fields.title: Good Win - But D- Overall
fields.content:
It was really nice to end the first half of the season with a win, especially in such a tight game as yesterday's, but overall the season has to go down as a failure for the Kings up to now. We should be a better team than Bristol, but having lost two out of three to the Bulls over the weekend we are a game behind them in the standings.

Everyone knows we are battling for second place, the Rhinos might win the South by as many as ten games, but I really believe we have the second best team in the conference. If we could just score a few more runs, things might be different. Our pitching is right up there with the best in the league, but to only score 85 runs in 29 games this season just isn't good enough.

Dean O'Merry was a really good signing for us, and has already helped us to win a couple of games that we might otherwise have lost, but we need a couple more like him if we are to get ahead of Bristol and stay ahead. We certainly need a lot of strengthening in the batting line-up if we are to have any hope of competing with Birmingham in the coming seasons.
